on public-html?

maybe Hixie was placing bets on how long it would take until the shit hit the fan
If so, I hope he won, because the rest of us lose.  >_<

Heh.
I was quite surprised that Sicking posted that about <em>
Oh and I agree with hsivonen about the media thing fwiw
It doesn't seem to have changed substantially since it was last discussed here and we were told it was about to change substantially
jgraham: i know, it's really a too silly discussion to get involved with
Bad sicking!
i'm just surprised when accessibility experts advocate misusing semantic elements in the name of accessibility
it's shocking that AT doesn't support <em>
no wonder the state of accessibility is so poor if we have to keep working around such AT vendors
the edit wars continued through the night
oh god
Hmm, HTML5 requires object@data served as image/* gets sniffed. Opera doesn't.
is unaware of anything needing it to be sniffedâ€¦
sniffed for what?
e.g. that image/png can carry image/gif
I suspect
Yeah
opera doesn't do that?
Oh, wait, I'm being dumb
is getting stuff mixed up in his mind
What we don't sniff is object served as text/plain
The spec seems to fail to set the resource type in that case
does the spec match mozilla?
http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/#the-object-element 4.7.4.4
It defines resource type when binary is false, but not when it is true
zcorpan: I think the spec doesn't say.
And then in 4.8 you then have an undefined variable.
Oh, it's set initially to unknown
decides to not try to follow
Look at the spec.
You have a PNG served as text/plain.
What happens?
uh, yeah, it gets sniffed as application/octet-stream by MIMESNIFF and thus sets binary to true, but doesn't say what happens next
or step 8 goes to the Otherwise case
falls into the otherwise case, no?
Which matches nothing.
right
file a bug
Yeah, was going to once someone checked I wasn't being silly. :)
wait, doesn't it match "If the resource type is an XML MIME type, or if the resource type does not start with "image/"" ?
I wasn't sure.
application/octet-stream is a type that does not start with "image/"
How is application/octet-stream the value of resource-type?
Like, where does "resource type" get set apart from to unknown?
"resource type" seems to be set by type=""
and the file extension
If you have <object data="data:text/plain,%89PNGâ€¦"></object>
so in our case it seems to be "unknown"
Indeed.
though "unknown" also doesn't start with "image/" :)
Indeed :)
whoa. Using CVS access to commit changes to a draft one isn't an editor of strikes me as a very bad idea despite good intentions.
Well, yes
"OFFICIAL WHININGS" haha

EXPERT OFFICIAL TECHNICAL QUESTION

don't fuck with the experts of this world

is assuming expertness is an inherited quality goverened by the rules of genetics
i take it you saw one of these superhero movies recently?
hmm, the "Errors that result in disproportionally poor performance" example seems to not be a very good example... http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/#syntax-errors
since the conforming alternative also has to check all open elements (once for each end tag)
and the shorter markup might be a perf win if the network is the slow part
Is it ever possible for an implied token to cause a "reprocess the token" to occur?
e
Ï€

jgraham: well for e.g. "

" the spec implies and then reprocesses

, which then implies and then reprocesses

, etc
e^(Ï€i)
jgraham: though i guess the implied token doesn't directly cause the reprocess
Right, the implied <head> is not itself reprocessed

Specifically the invariant I wonder about is whether all "reprocess the token" calls are the last thing that happens when you process a given token, so it is equivalent to just spinning the loop with the token
again
The obvious way this could break is if token A implies token B which is reprocessed before something else is done with token A
public-html needs an audio stylesheet tuned on Bob Marley
I shot the sheriff ?
anyone looked at MS's new grid css proposal?
micheil: in which terms

oh, nice

and also thinking that 1fr should be replaced with percentages
http://twitter.com/robinberjon/status/28976239926
with flex box, grid positionning, template layout and grid align, that makes 4 "layout" related stuff
only one of them has some implementations
I think the template layout stuff (if that was the "a b b c" stuff) was kinda bad
I haven't seen flex box or grid positionning
I like the ASCII art idea
very visual
http://www.w3.org/TR/css3-grid/
yeah, but doens't feel write for css
I wish microsoft came with a build of IE supporting their proposal
http://www.w3.org/TR/css3-flexbox/
Rik`: I'm interested in see the language look right in this case before a supporting demo
websockets are slightly different in that respect
(because you're not hand-writing network packets, yet you probably hand-write css)
without a supporting demo, you can't feel if the language is right
Rik`: well, I'm sure any front end developer knows what they would want
and currently the new MS grids thing is pretty much that.
(for me)
http://www.interoperabilitybridges.com/css3-grid-align/
at least 3
I don't remember if there are more
karlcow: template layout
ah yes indeed
http://www.w3.org/TR/css3-layout/
I think flexbox is different
micheil: I'm not sure front-end developers know exactly what they want
flexbox feels more like mozila's <hbox> <vboz> xul stuff
yep
Rik`: it'd be an idea to ask them somehow then
Rik`: then again, I'm probably not your average front end developer
and these days, the only way to get a new module implemented is to start the dance
and I don't really consider <hbox> / <vbox> stuff to really be grid layouts in the general sense
I'm not saying it's good (or bad)
just saying there are 4 layoutish modules
Rik`: yeah, true, but I think there should be a distinction between layout and grids
grids are a subset of layout
(in a way)
sort a grid is a layout, but a layout isn't necessarily a grid
like, flex box's box-lines: multiple; sounds like whitespace wrapping
which would possibly be useful in an odd way
it's box wrapping

"In my personal opinion, Adobe is doing a tremendous disservice to the publishing industry by encouraging these ineptly literal translations of print publications into iPad apps." http://www.subtraction.com/2010/10/27/my-ipad-magazine-stand
is there an scp parameter that makes it not copy files that already exist?
Why not use rsync?
then I should have used that from the beginning, no?
From the beginning of what?
ok, so rsync does what I need?
It's basically just a fancier remote file copy tool
i'll give it a try
(and it can work over SSH)
(Can't copy directly between two remote hosts, though)
so how does one use rsync?
rsync -a * remoteDir does not work
is terrible with command line manuals
What is remoteDir?
something@ip:dir
rsync -a ./ myname@somehost:/absolute/path/
The trailing slashes are significant.
I think that should work, though "dir" is interpreted relative to the home directory
Also probably good to use -avz instead of just -a.
rsync -avz localpath user@server:remote_path
no luck :/
What fails?
hmm
"bash: rsync: command not found" but it does give the help pages and all?
It needs to be installed on the remote system too, I think
Not sure if that's the problem here
Philip`: hmm, I don't think so.
hmm, how is the package called?
that looks like a local issue.
afaict it's not on the remote host
but apt-get does not find it
well, it also says "rsync error: remote command not found ..."
okay, maybe I'm wrong.
http://packages.ubuntu.com/search?keywords=rsync - it's just called rsync
running update first helps
working
thanks Philip`!
likes rsync
likes 'gzip --rsyncable' too
didn't know about that, interesting
does rsync also take care of deleting files on one end?
You have to add the --delete option for that.
and the first time this is slow but then it will be fast right?
Yes, if the files haven't changed much.

rsync doesn't store any extra metadata or anything - if you've already copied the files by some other means (scp or whatever) then rsync should immediately be fast (by only copying the changed portions of files)
oh, not too fast then for large datasets
It depends what you mean by "large".
And by "fast"
I regularly copy a couple hundred gigabytes with rsync and it takes only a few minutes, given that most of it hasn't changed.
By default it will skip files entirely if their size and mtime are the same.
well, lots of 10MB files of which I only added a few
Then it will only copy the newly-added files.
After the first time.
maybe lots of them changed then
well, I had already copied them before via scp
Are you definitely copying into the same location where the scp'd files are? (rsync makes it easy to get mixed up and accidentally add an extra subdirectory so things don't go where you expect)
Yes, make sure you keep a careful eye on trailing slashes.
It has some weird idiosyncratic way of interpreting them.
Like rsync -a dir1 dir2 will create dir2/dir1/ and fill it with dir1's contents.
You want to do rsync -a dir1/ dir2/ for it to sync the contents of dir1 with those of dir2.
it ended up in the same directory
About obsolete spec warnings: there have been non-zero occasions where browser developers accidentally looked at the static author view, and wondered where all the UA conformance requirements were
Oh, http://dev.w3.org/html5/spec-author-view/ is all a weird style now
which at least makes it distinct
though only about 300 words fit on my screen at once, which makes it horrid to browse through since there's way too much scrolling :-(
yeah, i wouldn't mind if that were wider
I get a visible region of 500x640 pixels, which is less than I find comfortable
(But apart from the narrowness (making it hard to read and making the code samples wrap too much), and some unreadably light blue text, and bugs with lists and stuff, it looks quite reasonable to me)
eh? why does http://dev.w3.org/html5/spec-author-view/ look like a quick blog post rather than a document of web scale importance?
and http://dev.w3.org/html5/spec/ ?
nvm / trust it'll be sorted out soon
webr3: "This is an out-of-date editor's draft. Please see the current editor's draft. Updates to this draft will resume shortly. Apologies for any inconvenience."
resume *shortly*
webr3: for the spec-author-view, it is just the table of contents
Rik`, looks the same when i click through to other bits of the doc..
are you talking about the look?
or the content ?
the look
it "looks" like a post on a free wordpress account somewhere, not a spec, or an author view of a spec, or anything near anything of any standing or importance, shich is a shame
I think, not sure that it's a new look that MikeSmith is working on with some developers who complained about the default look of W3C specs
no direct offense intended of course!
webr3, things which are dev.w3.org are editors drafts.
yup I know, you know, most of the web doesn't - they just see w3.org and think it's official "hot off the press" version
this is probably a moot convo tbh - unsure why I mentioned
yup.. if I google for "HTML 5" I get #1 wikipedia, #2 dev.w3.org/html5/spec/Overview.html - that about says it all to me
wanders off
is there no head/master/fork/branch/merge capabilities on dev.w3c?
and just wondering.. how exactly can an editors draft go out of date, as in why is the editors draft not the editors draft?
webr3: hixie's work is in http://svn.whatwg.org/webapps
webr3: Well, branches in CVS aren't exactly niceâ€¦
webr3: as part of his publication workflow, changes end up in dev.w3 CVS
gsnedders, good point
hober, so I assume the "real" editors draft is on whatwg, and sometimes they are pushed to dev.w3 cvs, as in dev,w3 version isn't actually the editors draft
hober, is the whatwg editors draft the editors draft of the HTML 5 specification, or of some other specification of which a subset could be considered HTML 5?
the whatwg draft is the sole draft of "HTML5 (including next generation additions still in development)"
AFAIK there's no distinction between the whatwg spec and some kind of whatwg "editor's draft"
it includes content that appears across several W3C drafts, including HTML5, plus some content that is not presently in any W3C draft
part of the publication flow is that the various w3c subset specs get pulled out of it
there is no distinction between Editor's Draft and Working Draft at WHATWG, it is just live
right
othermaciej, hober, okay i follow re whatwg HTML spec, so then what's the stuff on w3.org?
there are some automatic scripts that update the various Editor's Drafts in W3C CVS
when Ian checks in to the WHATWG version
A couple of days ago Ian stopped those automated updates and put a warning in place on the W3C Editor's Draft
yup, I'm just totally confused as to what the w3.org HTML 5 spec is then.. is it the spec for HTML 5 (still in development) or what?
the there are a few things at w3.org
Alternative explaination: there's this "source" file which loads of stuff gets generated from. <http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/complete.html> contains everything.
it's a snapshot of some of the work being done
there is the Editor's Draft, on dev.w3.org, which is the draft on track to become the W3C standard for HTML5
and there is the Working Draft at http://www.w3.org/TR/html5/
ok, so that will be HTML 5, as in the next HTML after HTML 4 ya?
which is a periodic snapshot (though eventually it will be frozen and HTML development will continue for the next version)
indeed, it will be the successor to HTML4.01
okay.. think I'm following - so is the whatwg spec the editors draft for the w3 HTML 5 spec? (yes or no?)
yesish
the editor only edits the whatwg source file
machines extract the w3c "editor's draft" from that mechanically
webr3, is there something which you need for a specific work? Or are you just asking by curiosity?
the whatwg spec is source material from which the w3c editor's draft is (was?) created
hober, maciej - thanks for clarifying (~ish!)

karlcow, nothing I specifically need, would like to know what's being standardized and can be pretty much relied on like - but primarily just trying to figure out what the hell the situation is, as I'm sure you're more than aware
from an outsiders point of view it's a bit wtf
hence why trying to clarify in some way
it can be somewhat confusing
realistically speaking, I think it's easy to remember whatwg.org/html5 as the spec URL
don't worry about what gets subsetted / split out over at the w3c
it's a live process (small p) for publication with improvements, sometimes errors. It has changed, and will change again. I'm pretty sure.
the whatwg spec converges with reality over time; the w3c spec hopefully will to, and many of us are working to make sure it does, but you never know.
otoh the w3c spec is the one that will most likely have a test suite that matches its normative requirements
so once it gets to that point, it is pretty likely browser vendors will run the test suite and change their code to match it
yup the last thing I'd do (hopefully) is indicate that you guys weren't putting in hard work, I see the mails on the lists flying by and sometimes try to keep up :p
web3r, are you an implementer or a Web developer? It's a bit harder for developer, plus the current spec is not necessary the best source for a Web developer.

othermaciej, cool that makes sense, so a [all the prototype stuff, experiments, stable stuff, trying stuff" is what whatwg, and a subset of that is going through standardization that will be implemented, tested and hold up as reliable over time ya?
well, nothing stops more experimental stuff from being implemented as well, though perhaps not as widely in that case
as far as creating content goes, if you want to deploy HTML5 content today, probably the best reference is one of the many books
s/going through standardization/going through standardization at w3c/
indeed, but hoping the "HTML 5" final spec is reliable accross vendors ya? that's the goal of standardization isn't it
(because it's also going through standardization at whatwg)
such as http://diveintohtml5.org/
but yeah, for a web dev reference, markp's and adactio's books are the way to go
webr3: in the very long run - probably, although it may be obsolete by the time it is completely final and fully implemented
found http://webr3.org/blog/about/
karlcow that's painfully out of date ;)
(Much like CSS 2.1)
webr3: revise your publication process then ;) I want to be more sure about which page I can rely on :p (kidding)
karlcow, I'm a developer primarily, around sem web fields, also member of rdfa wg, and generally ask lots of questions around webapps and related groups + note a few issues
lol I'll grey out that page and stick a link through to a markmail search for my name

tbh.. I still don't get the whatwg/w3c editors/chairs html/html5 thing, but doublt anything you can say will help that, or that anything I can say will make any form of difference to anything other than waste folks time
meh
"It's complicated"
hasn't even looked at the latest drama yet, but gets the impression it's relatively big
lmfao I remember saying that a few eyars ago about the ex
re "it's complicated" not re "it's relatively big"
heh
I love how the IEBlog posts so consistently contain veiled snipes against other browser vendors.
it is kind of weird
"For example, this page incorrectly initializes a canvas library for users of any IE version, rather than using IE9â€™s native canvas support."  Linking to arewefastyet.com.
Hardly anyone would even realize that was a snipe against Mozilla.  Maybe it's not, and I'm just being paranoid?
Apple would never let us blog stuff that snarky
It seems to be mandatory on IEBlog.
I don't know if that is the most clear-cut example but I have certainly seen swipes
Yeah, this one was more subtle.
A lot of times they'll just say something sort of innocuous-sounding and leave it up to you to figure it out from some words they've linked.

Like I remember something on their JS engine that said something like "Our engine is fast because it's fully integrated into the browser, not pluggable like some browsers", linking to pages on Nitro and V8.
Something like that.
They do that kind of thing all the time, though.

AryehGregor: I wonder who is writing the blog posts, but I can imagine that when you have been hit a lot of times because of the quality of your product with snarky comments, there is a kind of natural reaction, even when you are self control.
not necessary appropriate but understandable from a human point of view
karlcow, I'm pretty sure they're being edited professionally.  They have a very consistent tone.
AryehGregor: I suspect they are being written mostly by Program Managers on the IE team
has only a vague idea of what a Program Manager might be.
I am not totally sure what the role is (Apple doesn't have them)

sorry.. just started wondering why there aren't two distinct "HTML 5" and "HTML labs" type things that' don't touch, other than when something emerges as stable out of labs and in to html 5, something like mozilla + mozilla labs, or public stale vs dev beta?
but they are people who are part of a product team and are responsible for among other things designing the product and writing specs for everything, but not any coding

webr3, basically, HTML5 started in the WHATWG and then moved to the W3C.  In the W3C it has to follow W3C procedures and is answerable to W3C WG decisions and such.  But the WHATWG version was never retired, so it lives a life of its own.
freud'd i meant stable not stale
Sometimes the ones in charge of the W3C version disagree with the one in charge of the WHATWG version, and then sometimes they diverge.
In particular, the W3C process requires that the spec stabilize, so new pieces can't be added to it after a certain point.  But the WHATWG version has some parts stable and some parts unstable.
yup, but why not a stable and a labs type scenario, good feature in whatwg, let's standardize and push to official spec?
it could work like that, but the actual situation is more complicated
The WHATWG just has one document for everything, and marks sections individually by stability.
AryehGregor's description is more complete
Hixie prefers a single large spec to many small specs, and he runs the WHATWG in practice, so that's what the WHATWG publishes.

othermaciej, I'm aware and don't want to waste your time on this or get in to heavy politics, it just seems that making a clear distinction solves a lot of problems, as a friend said you can remove the address bar in mozilla labs without problem, remove it in firefox live and you get a huge bloody mess

The W3C has tended to push for somewhat smaller specs, so the WHATWG spec gets chopped up, and some pieces get dropped for various reasons, and a number of minor things get changed (like dropping examples that W3C members didn't like, etc.).
webr3: ultimately, for that conception to fly the relevant leadership of the W3C and WHATWG would have to agree
webr3, specs aren't comparable to software.  In particular, spec changes don't affect anyone immediately, and it doesn't make sense to have specs that contradict each other.
othermaciej, not much I can say to that :)

Whereas with software, shipping a new software version affects all users who download it in a very concrete way, and it makes sense to have lots of different variants of the same software flying around.

Basically, if you know the current "stable" version of the spec is wrong in some way, why would you *not* want to fix it?  It's not like software, where a bug fix in one place could cause some unexpected bug in another place.
That sort of thing in specs is only likely if you make fairly major changes.

AryehGregor, unsure.. if specs changes don't affect anyone immediately, and it doesn't make sense to have specs that contradict each other - then why the hell does dev.w3 html spec point to whatwg one, and what's all the fuss about the TR and editors drafts being out of date about then..?
Plus, the intended audience for specs is much more likely to be able to spot bugs.

webr3: The W3C Process (big P) has been relatively flexible by accomodating different type of WGs. (Many would argue we are not there yet and that's right). There is a trade-off between stability and dynamic changes.

The Lab idea is indeed interesting and it is something the goal of Member Submissions, and Incubator Groups. There is a new proposal being drafted on the table which is Community proposal. We will see how it evolves
I haven't looked at the latest hubbub yet, dunno about that.
AryehGregor, well you just mooted and disagreed w/ it all lol
s/something the goal/somewhat the goal/
speaking as an implementor, I think having a stable branch is beneficial for specs just as for software
karlcow, sounds interesting - is that the same community thing going on in w3 where there was a poll etc recently?
it is useful to have a core set of spec material that's relatively stable and covered by a comprehensive test suite, as a stable implementation base
webr3, let me fetch a link
othermaciej, speaking as a developer I totally agree, specially when you know the fine details have been covered
sometimes fixes have to be backported from the dev version, but that will likely not be the common case
when it does happen, it's good to have a process that ensures implementors are alerted ASAP, that test suites are updated, and so forth
basically the same kinds of reasons that stable branches are useful for software
othermaciej, fully agree
with one big spec, it's hard to even tell which parts are relatively stable
othermaciej, fully agree, again - it is a real PITA for a developer
I hate implementing stuff then finding it doesn't work everywhere, or hardly anywhere even
webr3: http://www.w3.org/2010/07/community a DRAFT in big bold accessible letters
you need to be very looped in to WHATWG to be able to tell which parts of the WHATWG spec are solid and unlikely to change, as opposed to which parts are still fairly experimental
that makes it harder to prioritize implementation work
now, I'm not particularly looking to force this approach on anyone
othermaciej, fully agree, yet again - it's kind of the point in standardization too
webr3, developers are probably not well served by reading specs anyway, unless they're about very old features.  You really need compatibility charts of some kind.
but I think that is what I find useful as an implementor (and moreso as a person who is responsible for prioritizing much of Apple's implementation work, in addition to doing part of it)
othermaciej, the stability markers in the WHATWG spec aren't good enough?
karlcow, ty for link - that's what i was thinking of, remember taking the poll etc and have read the doc - quite excited about it :)
AryehGregor: in practice, they haven't been that effective
ArayehGregor, no tbh not from where I'm standing they aren't useful

AryehGregor: I find that I have to rely on my inside knowledge of what has already been implemented or shipped by other vendors, which things have significant outstanding feedback, which items are brand new, etc

in the past, when there was less products and less implementers, the errata page was here to keep people informed about spec errors http://www.w3.org/2005/10/Process-20051014/tr#errata  But I guess in our stream world, a feed is more appropriate
i.e. knowledge that is out of band of the spec
what's useful is having a pretty reliable editors draft with standardized stuff in it that only has minor bugs
karlcow: It's a lot nicer for the errata to be inline
(Like, I know this has caused issues with ES for me)
othermaciej, isn't that the case with any large new standard or set of standards, though?  Is CSS3 much better?
gsnedders: yes :) in the context of now :) time changed.
AryehGregor: it is hard to tell which CSS3 modules are stable without inside knowledge, though I can usually assume that almost all of CSS2.1 is quite stable
othermaciej, but that's only because CSS2.1 is ancient.
HTML5 has practically no parts of comparable antiquity.
well, it has the HTML4-ish subset
which is comparably old in the wild, if not in draft form
CSS2.1 is actually an attempt to fix CSS2 which had the opposite problem - freezing too early
Yeah, but most of that is much more detailed than HTML4, so it's not necessarily stable.
it went to REC before it had actually gotten full interoperable implementation in mainstream browsers

AryehGregor: because the specs were written with a different mindset. It was about creating markup languages, not implementations guidelines. HTML 4 has been the first to enter a bit more in the details of implementations.
Yes, sure.
HTML 4 was not too concerned about detailed interop.
Then a generation of Web integrator have been familiarized with reading w3c specs. And now they have a culture shock. It will take time to adjust.
And I'm pretty sure the next generation will throw as much stone to what is done these days :) It's called history.
dunno..
I quite like reading a spec, implementing it, and seeing it work
and have a clear readable spec (nudge MikeSmith)
and one that doesn't crash my browser
but then I'm just one of millions
i also really like going through whatever/labs and trying new things..
older editions of HTML were more concerned with defining the syntax and abstract semantics rather than detailed processing requirements
yup, that is a big improvement - much of it is a big improvement
there's just no clear distinction between the "ooh try this" stuff and the "yes, use this" stuff
imo
this is wasting your time, apologies
webr3: don't worry about that. this is IRC after all. What's it for if not wasting time?
:) well tbh I've got a to-do list longer than my arm and should be concentrating on that
Only 26 posts?  That barely qualifies as drama.

I personally used the process of creating the document to listen to the users' requirements - I don't really care that much any more about the exact wording in the document, since I have heard them make their points and understand the intentions, which is more valuable to me - but it is important for the process and for W3C publications etc to get that document right and the group will be very happy to address all the concerns
AryehGregor: https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=603141

nessy: I don't really understand your point about process. Why is it important to get something right for "process" reasons? In general having documents with bigs lists of features without any implementation-level considerations seems very counter-productive, giving them any normative status doubly so
Understanding user needs is of course very important
volkmar, okay, noted that in the spec bug.

accessibility users have traditionally been under the impression that their needs are not considered, and been told that they need to express them explicitly to make a contribution to the process of defining a specification - so they are trying to adhere to "process"
unfortunately the word "requirement" can be very overloaded
Iv'e also called it a "wish list" in the past, but that's unfair to most of the needs expressed on that list, which are more than wishes and actual fundamental needs

nessy: I am not sure, but I think contributions more similar in form to that used by the rest of the community would work better. Specifically problem statements of the form "I have this problem using HTML video." possibly followed by "I need x to fix this problem" and then maybe a suggestion for the implementation details of x
At the moment we just have a list of lots of "I need x"
With no real way to tell what the priorities are and only guessses at the actual problem being solved
that's because a statement such as "I am blind and cannot watch video - I need a means that allows me to perceive video imagery in a different" isn't actually constructive
(insert: way)
the priorities are on the checklist
http://www.w3.org/WAI/PF/HTML/wiki/Media_Accessibility_Checklist
it references the user req doc for more detailed descriptions of each need
From that document it is hard to pick say the top 5 features that one would add to the spec in order to imporve accessibility
